bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1947

div1.p: Kean recalls that Howard's play, “Yellow Jack,” incorrectly shows Lazear infecting XY without his consent.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, March 17, 1947
div1.opener:
17 March '47
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
Here are a couple of clippings which
have been floating around on my
desk for several days which I thought
would amuse you. I remember Dr. Paul
Mazzuri quite well in Cuba, but cannot
recall any connection whatever with
Walter Reed, or the Yellow Fever Episode.
He was a nice fellow of average intelligence
and about the last person I could think
of to put forward such an astonishing
claim. I last saw him when I ran across him
in Paris, I think about 1912. As he was 82
when he died he had arrived at the age
when some men remember things that
never happened. As to the reappearance
of Sidney Howard's Yellow Jack. I was
invited to witness its first appearance but
never saw it as I didnt have the cash
to go to New York for that purpose.
My impression is that it represented
Lazear as having infected xy without
his consent, which I do not believe.
I have stuck in the Health News because
I have for many years been reading Dr
Paul B. Brooks weekly letter. “Dr. Jones says”
They are always sensible and usually amusing.
A request to the State Dept of Health will bring
it to you if you have two minutes a week to
spare for it. We had a fine visit from the
Irelands recently. He is still very lame
but is always the same wise and good
friend. He told me that now Col Siler
is out and driving his car. We agreed
that our prayers must have helped towards
his extraordinary recovery.

Are we not a fortunate nation to have
a great and wise man like General
Marshall to represent us at Moscow?
And President Truman's fine message
about Greece and Turkey! But you have
no time to waste on political talk.

I am hoping from day to day that
I will get a card from you to say:
“I have begun the Magnum Opus” “Am
writing provisional chapter headings”

Can you not take a Sabbatical year
and devote yourself to the M.O. It is the
only way that I can see for you to do it.
I think that Dr. Harvey Cushing did this

in order to write his Life of Osler.
You will necessarily have an assistant
to sift out the grain from the chaff for
you, and she could sift and classify
& make cross references. &c. &c.
Good Lord what a job it is!
I hope you will excuse my presumption
in telling you what you ought to do-
but I am so interested that I cannot
help it, and you are so good a friend that
I know you will not be offended.

And anyway you do not have to
answer this note, which began with
the intention only to write one page and
this is the fourth.
